title: Runtime error: invalid memory address or nil pointer dereference and a SEGV signal occurred
body:
When we use ```evm --value 1 -- code XXXXXX run ``` to run the byte code.

```
panic: runtime error: invalid memory address or nil pointer dereference
[signal SIGSEGV: segmentation violation code=0x1 addr=0x18 pc=0x4d6fe7]

goroutine 1 [running]:
fmt.Fprintf(0x0, 0x0, 0xb13359, 0xb, 0xc4201130d8, 0x1, 0x1, 0x3, 0x0, 0x0)
	/usr/lib/go-1.10/src/fmt/print.go:189 +0x77
main.runCmd(0xc420202f20, 0x0, 0x0)
	/build/ethereum-cdyJWd/ethereum-1.8.13+build14601+xenial/build/_workspace/src/github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/cmd/evm/runner.go:243 +0x105b
github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/vendor/gopkg.in/urfave/cli%2ev1.HandleAction(0xa1cea0, 0xb3b1e0, 0xc420202f20, 0xc420196900, 0x0)
	/build/ethereum-cdyJWd/ethereum-1.8.13+build14601+xenial/build/_workspace/src/github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/vendor/gopkg.in/urfave/cli.v1/app.go:490 +0xc8
github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/vendor/gopkg.in/urfave/cli%2ev1.Command.Run(0xb0cdb6, 0x3, 0x0, 0x0, 0x0, 0x0, 0x0, 0xb1dab6, 0x18, 0x0, ...)
	/build/ethereum-cdyJWd/ethereum-1.8.13+build14601+xenial/build/_workspace/src/github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/vendor/gopkg.in/urfave/cli.v1/command.go:210 +0xa36
github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/vendor/gopkg.in/urfave/cli%2ev1.(*App).Run(0xc420290b60, 0xc42001e0c0, 0x6, 0x6, 0x0, 0x0)
	/build/ethereum-cdyJWd/ethereum-1.8.13+build14601+xenial/build/_workspace/src/github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/vendor/gopkg.in/urfave/cli.v1/app.go:255 +0x6a0
main.main()
	/build/ethereum-cdyJWd/ethereum-1.8.13+build14601+xenial/build/_workspace/src/github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/cmd/evm/main.go:146 +0x55
```
the byte code is :
```

```

This apparently got it's own CVE : https://vulmon.com/vulnerabilitydetails?qid=CVE-2018-19184 . 
That's a bit odd, since this does not actually affect `geth`, but only the `evm` binary, which is not something that is exposed to attackers. It is trivial to produce a crash with the `evm`, e.g by supplying a lot of gas and allocating a terabyte of data. 

The actual crash is very quirky, though, since the stacktrace indicates that it happens because `os.Stderr` is `nil`. I haven't managed to reproduce it yet though

I think the reproduce-info is wrong. `value 1` produces ` error: insufficient balance for transfer`, and you wouldn't reach that clause (`runner.go:243`) unless you also provide `--statdump`.

Also, are you executing this on some particular quirky conditions that could cause problems with `stderr` ?
I just reproduced it without "--value 1" option.
Could you give any additional info about the system you're running it on ?
Also, try with `--code 6040`. I would expect this to trigger regardless of what actual code you use...

> Also, try with `--code 6040`. I would expect this to trigger regardless of what actual code you use...

Exactly...
not a geth issue ... not worth of investigating at all
The issue was caused by this commit, fb9f7261ec51e38eedb454594fc19f00de1a6834, which had been reverted by this commit 83e2761c3a13524bd5d6597ac08994488cf872ef, not a problem since v1.8.14.

> Could you give any additional info about the system you're running it on ?

environment
go version go1.10 darwin/amd64

repro
1. cd PATH-TO-go-ethereum; git checkout v1.8.13
2. make all
3. ./build/bin/evm --code 6040 --statdump run
